name: Deus Ex: Game of the Year Edition
description: The year is 2052 and the world is a dangerous and chaotic place. Terrorists operate openly - killing thousands; drugs, disease and pollution kill even more. The world's economies are close to collapse and the gap between the insanely wealthy and the desperately poor grows ever wider.
minimum_requirements: 300 MHz Pentium II or equlivalent, Windows 95/98, 64 MB RAM, DirectX 7.0a compliant 3D accelerated video card 16MB VRAM, Direct X 7.0a compliant sound card, Direct X 7.0a or higher (included), 150MB uncompressed hard drive space, Keyboard and Mouse

reviews.review_text: Where it all began. Can't believe that this was released on Windows 2000, 15 years ago! Still to this day we are gifted with excellent mods for it, currently Caustic Creative are developing a wonderful overhaul mod named Deus Ex: Revision (be sure to check it out!).  This was one of my first childhood games, I can still remember certain stealth patterns to the levels. Really good to revisit from time to time and like I mentioned, mods really revitalise an old classic. JC Denton the badass! The question is, which ending did you choose?  For those wondering, the storyline of the Deus Ex series is as follows;  2027 – Human Revolution 2029 – Mankind Divided 2052 – Deus Ex 2072 – Invisible War  So the events of the original come AFTER the events of Human Revolution.

NOTE:  Since GameSpy was shut down, to continue multiplayer and to be able to see the servers, visit  www.deusexnetwork.com  with instructions on how to change the masterserver address.   Deus Ex: Game of the Year Edition is a masterpiece. If you didn't play it yet - you definetly should. An exceptional mix of FPS / RPG / Stealth / Adventure. Took me 62 hours to get the whole 3 endings and still didn't get enough of it.  You get to play as UNATCO (United Nations Anti-Terrorist Coalition) agent J.C. Denton. Not a simple agent, but an augmented bionic man. Find out betrayal, carefully choose who your friends and enemies are and, finally, decide the fate of the world.  The game gives you freedom in everything. You don't get a Game Over except you get killed, throw yourself from a building, drink booze or do drugs till you overdose, or smoke cigarettes till you get cancer. Overwise it doesn't care what path you choose as long as you can survive the consequences. And there are choices to be made every instance. Use lockpicks to open a door or find a key for it, look for computer login info or use your computer skills to hack it, find acces codes for door keypads or use multitools to disable them, jump on your enemies and slaughter them the way you like it, or look for alternative ways, tunnels, air ventilation systems, etc, and avoid unnecessary kills. It's very rewarding also. A lot of augumentations to choose from, a big variety of weapons, ammo, tools, enemies, locations, etc, which will increasingly keep you interested in going through this cyberpunk conspiracy story.  Proclaim yourself God, be part of The Illuminati, or plunge the world into another Dark Age. The choice is yours.

Pretty much objectively one of the best games of all time. Nearly every aspect of this game has aged very well. The plot is engaging and intelligent. The gameplay allows you to approach nearly any situation in nearly any way you wish and the levels are so damn big and well designed that you will often find all sorts of alternate ways to do things each time you play.   For that matter there are so many little things and side missions you can find in the game that it is almost always worth exploring everywhere that you can. Not to mention that the game WILL reward you for exploring.   Building a character is so much fun and there are so many things that you can specialize in and it will change the way you play the game in very significant ways.   The story is very malleable and you can pretty much do anything you want and rather then giving you a 'MISSION FAILED' thing when you kill a story important character the game will mold to your actions.   The Music is awesome and really captures the atmosphere of the game.  Pretty much the only two things I could imagine somebody objecting to would be the graphics and voice acting. Which sure, I mean the graphics ARE pretty ugly but if such an old game having bad graphics bothers you so much then you can easily download some graphics mods to make the game much more paletable for you. (As a side note this game has a pretty decent modding community you should check out.)  And while the voice acting can be pretty bad it (thankfully) is the funny kind of bad so you shouldnt be bothered too much by it.
This game is Augmented. 11/10

I played through this game fully back in the day when it originally launched, and I lost myself in it. Whilst the game hasn't aged well visually, and the voice acting is terrible, the amount of freedom afforded to the player to make decisions is still impressive. The feeling of reactivity and decision on the player is quite exhilerating, especially as the game goes on and decisions have further reaching impact.  The opening can feel clumsy, but as you realise how immersive the level of reaction can be, and the opportunities you have to make meaningful decisions, the game really comes to life. The endings lack a little impact due to how they are presented, but the journey to making those decisions is worth the investment, the game is a true classic. It's a shame most games since have focused more on narrative and mechanics as separate elements, rather than blending decisions into meaningful influences on the game (as an aside, I think the closest to achieve this other than Deus Ex is Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines).  Whilst Deus Ex: Human Revolution never lived up to the freedom and openness and impact that the original set in place, the two slot together beautfully lore-wise, so if you've played one and not the other, I'd highly recommend them both.

It's the Greatest PC Game of All Time. It says so on the box, I swear! If it doesn't, ask anyone who's left Liberty Island. They'll tell you so.  Incredible gameplay, with an interesting world, moody graphics, and a sexy ambient soundtrack that strikes the 'comfy' cyberpunk nerve like none other. You might not immediately warm up to it, but you'll quickly learn to love what has been created here. Deus Ex is a meaty as hell game, and one of the indisputed kings of Player Agency.  Also, manually save your progress often. Trust me.  Have fun!

If you need a game that was totally ahead of its time - here is one. Deus Ex is one of the very first, fully realized sandboxes, learning heavily from previous titles like Thief or System Shock, the game offers player near unmatched freedom in approaching the objectives, while the game's basic rules, smart level design and multitude of items only support that idea. Yes, it looks ugly - no doubt about that - and it does have some truly awful shooting mechanics, but once you get into it - you'll love it.
What a game.
A uniquely compelling game with an intricate storyline, vast amounts of dialogue and interesting technical presentation.
The best game ever made, period.
A game that was and still is ahead of its time in writing, sound design, and flexibility.

This is my fave game of all time and has been since younger childhood. The first time playing through this was the best experience in any game ever. Absolutely mind-blowing. I just wish I could reexperience playing it for the first time because by now I've played over 300 hours on it (including my disk). This and the Thief series are the most magical games to have a first playthrough of ever. This game has a lot of flaws that also add to its charm, so instead of the normal Pro's and Con's, I'm going to have a Charmy Flaw list as well.  Pros: +Great sound design +One of the most beautiful soundtracks in anything ever +Incredible writing and story +Great UI +Sick weapons (OP Dragon's Tooth Sword) +Characters (also a con...I'll get to that) +Heaps of interesting locations +Sub-plots and mini storylines +Optional sidequests are great +Non-linear, multiplayer outcomes, ways of doing things +Five playthroughs worth of stuff to find and then some (not exaggerating) +Perfect length (took me 22 hours first playthrough) +Multiplayer ways of playing, lethal, non-lethal, stealth, all-out, no augs etc. +Great dialogue system +Upgradeable skills +Maximum replayability +A really good roleplaying multiplayer (if you want it to be) that no one has ever cared about ever +Shadow, stealth system, Thief like but not invisible +Have to mention UI again, I mean, it's REALLY good +Feels like a real world ('Who will help the widow's son?', 'Excuse me?', 'Oh sorry, I thought you were someone else.') +Nice plotwist early on +Every character you meet is memorable, every one. That dude shouting holy stuff at Battery Park. That rude newspaper girl in Hong Kong. That annoying boy who's annoying to the rude girl in Hong Kong. That ♥♥♥♥ who keeps asking you stuff in Kell's Kitchen (Used Car Salesman?). Those two lesbians in the club in Hong Kong etc. +The best bossfights in any game ever +Will update review in the future  Cons: -Some weapons are useless or pointless (PS20, Stealth Pistol etc.) -Most augmentations are useless/pointless (only helpful ones are speed, health recover, strength and that's about it. You can go through the whole game without them if you really want) -Difficulty gets a lot harder all of a sudden at the end -Graphics look bad for 2000 -Default FOV is quite small -A lot of characters become unimportant later on or dissapear completely, pretty much everyone from the beginning -Will update review in the future  Flaws/Charms: *♥♥♥♥♥♥, almost racist voice-acting *Hearing footsteps through rooms *AI getting stuck opening doors *Will update review in the future  Sound: 9/10 Graphics: 4/10 (looked ♥♥♥♥ then, looks ♥♥♥♥ now) Gameplay: 10/10 Content/Replayability: 10/10 Overall: 10/10  Get this. A true legend, Deus Ex is the ultimate game, the game every other game wants to be. It is complete with a story worthy of a trilogy of books and their respective movies and an amazing, breathtaking, dynamic gameplay. What's your style? You could hide in the shadows, lockpick that door, walk around slowly, and silently take down that guard with your electric prod, or, you could blast through that iron door with a LAM and annihilate all enemies with your plasma rifle, or perhaps you could hack into their security system and turn it against them, the possibilities are infinite, but beware, your actions, decisions, and even the way you play the game WILL have consequences. Few games exist in this mortal plane that provide the degree of choice and freedom Deus Ex provides.  Want to run around and bludgeon everyone on Liberty Island to death with a crowbar? Go ahead.  Want to explode every dog in Hong Kong? Go ahead.  The fact that this game came out in 2000 is mindboggling. Sure, the graphics look like ♥♥♥, but the massive levels and sheer scope of the experience as a whole more than compensate. The ending(s) alone make for one of the most memorable choices in gaming history.  Buy it.

Need I say more? This is the best PC game of all time. Nuff said!  For me, the best game of all time has to be Deus Ex. This game combines different genres (FPS, RPG, Stealth and action) into one and it was the very first piece of media that actually made me think about socio-political issues in real life. It also taught me the consequences of choice and how different choices can lead to opposite or even unexpected results. It might be a dated game by today’s standards, but this game actually respects the player by interacting with him/her through choices and liberty of gameplay to reach from point A to point B while maintaining the player grasped into the plot that is masterfully delivered and never feels unrealistic or over the top. It makes you think on the final outcome of all the choices and paths you have taken and can even make you second-guess yourself for doing it. This game teaches you that there is no right or wrong, just different ways to do things.

This is one of the best games I've ever played.  It's an action/RPG first person game with a lot of different ways to play. You can go inside a building through the front door, or you can find a back entrance. You can hack computers, digital locks, and security consoles, but you can also get the password somewhere. You can pick locks, but you can get the key from somebody. You can kill your enemies, but you can just avoid encountering them at all.  The level designs are just brilliant. They're big, but not huge. You can easily memorize them, so it's easy not to get lost. Some of the levels are visited more than once and it feels different everytime, yet you still remember the places.  The graphics aren't amazing and they may look outdated, but they fit the atmosphere perfectly. The music is great and every location has its own soundtrack that fits to what you're currently doing.  The story is great and a little bit complex with conspiracies here and there, but there's not much to tell without spoiling it. This game is set in 2052 and it takes place in a chaotic world filled with terrorists, drugs, diseases, and augmented humans. There's a lot of memorable characters in this game, and every single one of them has their own personality. You can kill some of the important characters but instead of failing the mission, it will change the story and you will have to face the consequences.  In short, it's a great classic game with a great story and music that combines RPG, FPS, action, and stealth elements with a lot of different playstyles to choose.
Simply one of the best cyberpunk RPGs out there.

YES, Deus Ex was and still is great.. Hard for me to say though, because my impression of it is from 2000, not current. Even back then it's graphics were a bit ugly but Deus wasn't about graphics, graphics didn't make Deus Ex the game that made video games worth playing. It wasn't just 'Here's a firearm now go kill whatever you simple-minded.... NO, Deus Ex was much more than that..    Deus Ex was all about the large world to explore and investigate. To play it the way you wanted to play. You didn't have to be a homicidal maniac, you could use stealth and wit. Afterall Deus Ex was/is about ambiance and if you go around killing all the NPC's is does lose the ambiance. It also impacts the storyline..
